case_vignette: A 34-year-old Ethiopian woman who recently moved to the United States presents for evaluation to a surgical outpatient clinic with painful ulceration in her right breast for the last 2 months. She is worried because the ulcer is increasing in size. On further questioning, she says that she also has a discharge from her right nipple. She had her 2nd child 4 months ago and was breastfeeding the baby until the pain started getting worse in the past few weeks, and is now unbearable. According to her health records from Africa, her physician prescribed antimicrobials multiple times with a diagnosis of mastitis, but she did not improve significantly. Her mother and aunt died of breast cancer at 60 and 58 years of age, respectively. On examination, the right breast is enlarged and firm, with thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and an ulcer measuring 3 × 3 cm. White-Gray nipple discharge is present. The breast is tender with axillary and cervical adenopathy. Mammography is ordered, which shows a mass with a large area of calcifications, parenchymal distortion, and extensive soft tissue and trabecular thickening in the affected breast. The patient subsequently undergoes core-needle and full-thickness skin punch biopsies. The pathology report states a clear dermal lymphatic invasion by tumor cells.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful sore in my right breast that's getting bigger, and there's some liquid coming out from my nipple.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for the last 2 months.
Do you have any history of similar symptoms or breast issues in the past?
I was prescribed medication for mastitis several times before, but it didn't really get better.
Have you had any breast imaging, like a mammogram or ultrasound, done recently?
Yes, I had a mammogram done recently.
What did the results of the mammogram indicate?
The results showed a mass with a lot of calcifications, changes in the normal breast tissue, and thickening of the soft tissue.
Have you gotten a biopsy of the breast mass?
Yes, I underwent a needle and skin punch biopsy.
What were the results of the biopsy?
The biopsy showed that tumor cells had spread into the lymph channels in my skin.
Do you have a personal or family history of breast cancer or other cancers?
My mother and aunt both died of breast cancer.
Are you currently on any medications or treatment for this condition?
No, I am not currently on any medications for this condition.
Final Diagnosis: Inflammatory Breast Cancer

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with a painful sore in her right breast that has been growing larger, accompanied by liquid coming out from her nipple. She has been experiencing these symptoms for the last 2 months and has been prescribed medication for mastitis multiple times without improvement. She recently had a mammogram done, which showed a mass with calcifications, changes in the normal breast tissue, and thickening of the soft tissue. Additionally, she underwent a needle and skin punch biopsy, which revealed tumor cells spreading into the lymph channels in her skin. The patient also has a family history of breast cancer, as her mother and aunt both died from the disease. She is not currently taking any medications for her condition.
trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Breast abscess or inflammatory breast cancer.
